translation.title: A Question About the Dimension of Neither Perception Nor Non-Perception

previous.name: A Question About the Dimension of Nothingness

segments.en: 8. A Question About the Dimension of Neither Perception Nor Non-Perception
“They speak of this thing called the ‘dimension of neither perception nor non-perception’.
What is the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception?

segments.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
This is called the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

segments.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
segments.en: And so … I was entering and remaining in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

segments.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato ākiñcaññāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
segments.en: While I was in that meditation, perceptions and attentions accompanied by the dimension of nothingness beset me.

segments.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

segments.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ pamādo, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
segments.en: Don’t neglect the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, brahmin! Settle your mind in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception; unify your mind and immerse it in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

segments.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
segments.en: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

segments.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya … pe … mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
segments.en: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

suttaplex.blurb: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
